page.title: 13Landscape
page.content: The area in question is lying on a small part of{that much-weathered {chalk outcrop}that covers South East lowland England in a range of hills known more locally as{the Chilterns. Beyond the area to the North and South vales spread extensively.Hence the {local sub-rock consists of chalk and {clay.}Immediately to the North,the {urbanised Hitchin Gap}marks an interr- uption in the chalk outcrop where the Chilterns end and the more exposed Cambridgeshire-facing East Anglian Heights begin.Thus our area is a fine example of{chalk upland scenery}of the more wooded North Hertfordshire variety.{The relief is undulating}and at times scarps weave an irregular East to West trail.In other words some familiar downland scenery is to be found - open country meeting woods,dry valleys and few surface streams.
